resources.string:
This app aims to be a useful tool for students of astrology.

Please sign in with Google for storing profiles and texts online, and for sharing with others.

For full documentation, see Help in the menu.
Database has not been properly created. Please reinstall app.
This text may not be changed
There is no text available for this symbol, but you can write your own interpretation.

Sphinx Astrology

Index

  • Sphinx Astrology
  • FAQ
  • Horoscope
  • Profiles
  • Edit Profile
  • Edit Text
  • Text Syntax
  • Text Links
  • Text Tags

Sphinx Astrology

Edit Profile

Enter name of the profile, for a person it should be the first and second name, or it can be some other name if it refers to a specific point in time, e.g. a solar eclipse or similar.

Date & Time

Date should be in the format "YYYY-MM-DD". Time should be in the format "HH:MM:SS", but "HH" and "HH:MM" are accepted. Time can be omitted, in which case "12:00" will be used. Only number input is accepted, dashes and colons are inserted automatically.

Location

Location can be a city, place or even street address, be general or specific. Leave the field empty to use current location. You can also enter exact longitude and latitude coordinates in the format "DDDXMMSS DDDXMMSS", where 'X' the direction, e.g. 'E', 'W', 'N', 'S'. Press the globe button to the right for finding locations. Select the correct location in the list below.

Daylight Saving Time is set automatically, but may be set manually also.

Advanced

Advanced data permits fine adjusting the horoscope.

See Also

Sphinx Astrology
FAQ

Sphinx Astrology

Text Syntax

A very simple type of markup can be applied for styling and formatting text. It's been specifically designed for soft keyboards on mobile devices. The basis for this markup is a subset and combination the well known Markdown, Txt2Tag and AsciiDoc.

Paragraphs

Paragraphs are created with line breaks. A blank line makes a new paragraph.

Headers

Headers are created with either equal (=) or hash (#) signs, and the number of signs defines the header level, e.g. "## Header" makes a header level 2. Instead of repeating the same sign, a number can be added, e.g. "### Header" can be written as "#3 Header". Headers must end with a line break.

#3 Header

Becomes:

Header

Quotes

Quotes are created with the greater than sign (>). Each line in the quote must start with a ">" and an optional space "> ". Quotes can have many lines, and can also have sub-quotes, e.g. ">>Quote" generates a quote of two levels.

> Astrology is a Language.
> If you understand
> this language,
> The Sky Speaks to You.

Becomes:

Astrology is a Language. If you understand this language, The Sky Speaks to You.
Text Styles

Text can be styled in many ways: *bold* becomes bold, /italic/ becomes italic, _underline_ becomes underline, ~strike~ becomes strike, ^sup^ becomes sup, +big+ becomes big, and -small- becomes small. All styles can also be combined */_~multi~_/* becomes multi.

Styles can only be applied to the beginning and ending of words with single signs. To apply a style anywhere in the text, use the sign twice, e.g. m**i**x//e//d becomes mixed.

Comments

Comments in a text are created with a percent sign (%). Each line starting with "%", are hidden. Entire blocks can be hidden by wrapping between three percent signs "%%%" on separate lines:

%%%
This text will not be visible. It can be a reminder, note or unfinished text.
%%%

Horizontal Lines

Horizontal lines are created with two or more dashes "--" on a separate line (blank lines above and below):

--

Becomes:

The Back-Slash

If you want to use a special sign in your text without using it for styling, you can prefix it with a backslash, e.g. "\\+text\\+" becomes +text+. This applies to all special signs and formatting.

There is also tags and links, which adds some nice features when writing texts. Links makes it possible to link texts together, and tags adds special signs and symbols etc.

See Also
